report_title: Industry Report on Music Production and Distribution
executive_summary: Major record labels have finally adapted to the new age. While labels enjoyed strong growth before the Internet, the rise of illegal file sharing and the corresponding decline in album sales pressured the industry over the past two decades. The rapid adoption of streaming services has pushed album sales down even more and challenged major labels who needed to prepare for the fundamental shift to online music streaming. Still, things are on the mend for major labels as they have successfully adapted to the new streaming landscape.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Streaming platforms like Spotify and Apple Music, which boast an expansive music library, have met consumers' desires for a varied supply of old and new music. This has devastated album sales and siphoned demand from physical music consumption and digital downloads. With the emergence of music streaming platforms, consumers do not need to buy a digital album and only buy physical albums in the case where they prefer the tangible experience or are hobbyists who enjoy collecting physical media such as vinyl records.

The shift to streaming has combined with the expansion of social media apps like TikTok, YouTube and Instagram to create new low-cost distribution channels. TikTok especially has emerged as a force of nature in the music industry and is responsible for some of music's biggest hits over the past five years, like Sam Smith and Kim Petras's "Unholy," which immediately rose to number one on Billboard's Hot 100 list and went on to win a Grammy for Best Pop Duo.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Big Three Buy Out Indie Labels
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Nearly three-quarters of the industry is controlled by Universal Music Group (UMG), Warner Music Group (WMG) and Sony Music Entertainment (SME), collectively known as the Big Three. Because labels can't rely on album sales anymore, many are expanding the roster of copyrights to better monetize streaming by increasing their presence on the platforms.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The US Copyright Office upped the standards for royalty rates from streaming services to labels at the end of 2022, so major labels can expect elevated revenue from their largest segment. While major labels have adapted to streaming, higher rates will help compensate for previous losses from declining purchases. At the same time, mounting royalty rates will lead labels to experience a slump in profitability, especially if they cannot pass on these additional costs to consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Album Sales Will Return to Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While album sales have consistently fallen over the past decade, major labels will benefit from growing sales of physical albums, restoring some of the industry's most high-margin revenue. Contrary to early fears, streaming has not entirely cannibalized physical music sales. Instead, streaming has complemented physical sales by introducing music to new audiences and encouraging fans to explore artists' entire discographies, including their back catalog available on physical formats. Still, album sales are past their prime and major labels won't be able to rely on them for consistent revenue.

Because of the intense competitive atmosphere created by streaming and social media, major labels must leverage their resources to maintain market share in the music industry. These labels will continue integrating new tech, like artificial intelligence and machine learning, to better understand listeners' behavior.

industry_definition: Record labels are responsible for finding musical talent, recording their work and selling it to retail outlets. The ability to oversee distribution of physical media and negotiate comprehensive publishing deals separates major labels from smaller independent labels. Major labels also commonly have deeper and broader talent rosters.
key_trends: Labels compete for talented artists. Establishing a solid reputation gives major labels bargaining power, but offered contracts must be competitive to secure a deal.
Music marketing is intense. Artists compete for audiences' attention, but the Big Three major labels have secured the ability to influence what music gets the most play.

Revenue has grown as labels adapted to streaming. Album sales have continued to fall, but redrafting contracts and negotiating royalty rates has allowed major labels to more than makeup for lost sales.
Social media is becoming vital. High-profile songs are counting on TikTok to find an audience, which has boosted competition in the industry.
The Big Three are securing legacy catalogs. UMG recently acquired Neil Diamond's entire discography, WMG now owns David Bowie's songbook, and SME bought Bob Dylan's portfolio.
Major companies are investing in new revenue streams. UMG has announced a partnership with Endel to enter the AI space, and other companies are likely to soon follow.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers aged 13 to 24 have historically provided lower revenue for major labels and their artists because they have low disposable income and purchase fewer albums. The shift to online streaming has made younger consumers more critical to reach than ever, as they listen to music at higher rates than some older age groups and can now generate revenue for labels through plays.

Consumers between 25 and 34 are active listeners and are well-connected to cultural and societal trends, making them a large client base for labels and artists. These consumers have more disposable income than younger listeners, making them a prime market for premium subscription services and music.

Consumers between the ages of 35 and 54 have higher disposable income and can afford to buy physical albums, raising revenue for labels and artists. Mixed technological literacy makes this group less likely to switch to streaming platforms online, and many listen to music through traditional routes like radio or CDs.

Consumers between the ages of 35 and 54 have higher disposable income and can afford to buy physical albums, raising revenue for labels and artists. Mixed technological literacy makes this group less likely to switch to streaming platforms online, and many listen to music through traditional routes like radio or CDs.

Music plays less of a role in the lives of consumers 55 and older, but an aversion to streaming services helps offset losses from lower listening rates. An estimated one-third of all consumers are older than 55, but this group is only responsible for less than 30.0% of major labels' revenue. The pandemic and the associated work stoppages and business closures led many older demographics to adopt music streaming platforms as they gained unprecedented access to a catalog of music unmatched by physical locations.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: A rise in disposable income will boost consumers' spending on music via digital or physical outlets. Although physical album sales have continually dropped for over a decade, streaming music subscription sales climb as consumer purchasing power rises, benefiting the industry. Despite concerns over economic uncertainty, a resilient job market continued to push back expectations and the economy continues to grow. However, the cost of living continues to be high, affecting disposable income levels.

business_locations.location_description: Major labels focus on metropolitan areas that serve as bustling cultural hubs and Los Angeles is the prime location for the music industry. In fact, California holds a staggering share of all major labels in the United States. The West's major cities attract aspiring artists and give major labels a steady stream of potential talent to sign and create music with. The heavy presence of artists and musicians also translates to an easily accessible workforce of established and skilled audio engineers, music marketers and event promoters.

The Southeast is the largest region by both population and size, so it naturally hosts several major labels. Atlanta and Miami have a strong presence in the music industry and are located in the Southeast. Country and blues music have long been rooted in this region, especially in Memphis and Nashville, Tennessee. Tennessee is home to less than one-tenth of the all major record labels in the US.

NYC's long history and diverse cultural composition have made the metroplex an epicenter for music and artistry, so many major labels operate in the area in order to capitalize on the talent. The Mid-Atlantic has several other large cities, like Philadelphia and Washington, DC, that host their own vibrant music scenes as well.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Intellectual property is covered by the US government
regulations_points.regulation_description: Many laws govern fair use and copyrighted material, protecting the copyrights of major labels. The Audio Home Recording Act of 1992 exempts noncommercial usage from legal action. Still, the No Electronic Theft Law enables criminal prosecution for sound recording violations even when there's no commercial gain.

The Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works is the primary international regulation in an era when the borderless internet requires international overseers to play a greater role. This law includes rules for the protection of works, including the right for the copyright owner to authorize reproduction, translation, public performance, communication and adaptation of their work.

regulations_points.regulation_title: New laws help adapt to streaming
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Music Modernization Act (MMA) of 2018 introduced three collective initiatives that established a nonprofit agency for negotiating royalty rates from streaming services, broadened copyright protections and set public domain entry dates for old songs.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Navigating copyright and contract laws can be very difficult for new entrants, and hiring knowledgeable staff that can handle government regulations is expensive.
Music is expensive to create and major labels must also pay for distributing and marketing new releases. New entrants must have massive capital to handle the entire process.

Established record labels have strong brand recognition, vast networks, and decades of experience in the industry, making it challenging for new entrants to differentiate themselves and gain a foothold in the market.

Music production requires a vast team of technically skilled audio engineers, producers and artists. Major labels usually work with those who have established a solid reputation, making them even more expensive to hire.

basis_points.basis_description: Labels compete for talented artists. Establishing a solid reputation gives major labels bargaining power, but offered contracts must be competitive to secure a deal.
Music marketing is intense. Artists compete for audiences' attention, but the Big Three major labels have secured the ability to influence what music gets the most play.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The Big Three dominate the market
concentration_points.concentration_description: Sony Music Entertainment (SME), Warner Music Group (WMG) and Universal Music Group (UMG) are commonly called "the Big Three" because of their overwhelming presence in the music industry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Consolidation in the industry is low
concentration_points.concentration_description: In part because of the existing high level of concentration, most acquisitions don't actually come out of the Major Label Music Production Industry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major labels might lose their edge
concentration_points.concentration_description: Indie labels are more willing to take a risk on aspiring talent and major labels have the capital to avoid these potential losses by simply buying an indie label with a solid roster of copyrights and popular artists.
The digitization of the music industry has lessened some of the advantages major labels enjoy and reduced the benefits economies of scale bring.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Scouting out potential artists can be costly, and many signees get advances that are accounted for under this segment.
Major labels encounter various legal fees relating to contract negotiation, intellectual property protection, licensing and clearance, as well as dispute resolution.
Producing music is extremely labor intensive and relies on highly skilled artists and producers to create songs audiences will enjoy.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Because of its low price point and cultural value to many consumers, demand for music is generally stable. How consumers prefer to listen to music does shift, though and the rapid adoption of streaming has introduced steady listening activity that spreads revenue out over time instead of the large spikes through big releases associated with album sales.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The price of music has remained low
volatility_points.volatility_description: While the pandemic led to a global economic slowdown and a contraction in real household disposable income in 2020-21, there was an acceleration in the adoption of audio streaming due to ease of access and the closure of physical stores during lockdown periods.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: What genres are in demand from consumers shifts with time, and music preferences vary widely by social, cultural, economic and demographic factors. Major labels offset drops in demand for one genre by keeping a roster of varied artists serving different markets.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Audio quality is more important than ever
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: High-tech headphones and speakers have enabled consumers to be more particular than ever about the technical fidelity of their music.

FAQs.question: Subscriptions to streaming services increased. How did this affect your company?
FAQs.answer: Changes in how individuals consume music have led to major shifts in how record labels generate revenue. As physical and digital album sales drop, it is critical that labels are able to pivot toward new ways of generating revenue.

FAQs.question: How has the prevalence of illegal downloading or streaming affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: As streaming services have become more popular, music piracy has become less of a problem for major music labels. That being said, it is still a concern for industry players and illegal streaming could pose a potential threat moving forward.

FAQs.question: The music style and the way it is heard tends to vary based on age. What strategies have you employed to ensure you engage well with your core audience? Are you implementing strategies to expand your consumer base?
FAQs.answer: Major music labels are active in a highly competitive market that is constantly changing. Labels must understand their core audience and pursue ways to expand their reach across all demographics.

FAQs.question: How have changes in technology affected the costs associated with serving your customers? What portion of your distribution is now attributed to streaming services?
FAQs.answer: While major labels have had to invest in infrastructure to provide music via streaming services, these investments are expected to lead to long-term cost savings. The music industry is highly vulnerable to technological changes that may adversely affect their distribution channels.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, particularly regarding data storage, computing power and other factors?
FAQs.answer: Major labels have increasingly emphasized streaming services as mobile devices have allowed music to be played anywhere. Data analysis is key to understanding new consumer preferences and trends.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep up with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: Being able to provide music across a variety of mobile platforms is crucial to the success of major music labels.

FAQs.question: Have any recent regulatory changes significantly affected your operations or relationship with distributors?
FAQs.answer: Recently, major music labels have not faced increased regulatory scrutiny. That being said, record labels constantly fight for agreements with streaming services that are more favorable to their interests.

FAQs.question: The record label industry is highly concentrated. Are you or your competitors facing scrutiny from antitrust litigation?
FAQs.answer: Because of the highly concentrated nature of the industry, there is a possibility that further merger and acquisition activity could raise red flags.

FAQs.question: Has technological change positively affected your company's financial performance?
FAQs.answer: The monetization of streaming services has helped turn around the financial performance of major music labels as consumers move away from purchasing physical or digital albums.

FAQs.question: Having a diverse range of clients
FAQs.answer: Having a large and diverse catalog of prior hit releases provides a stable and profitable revenue stream without any significant additional investment. It is important to have a mix of talent that appeals to a range of audiences.

FAQs.question: Control of distribution arrangements
FAQs.answer: As physical and digital album sales continue to decline, it is vital that labels position themselves to capitalize on the transition to streaming services. Some labels with popular artists in their portfolio may be able to negotiate a more favorable contract with big-name streaming services than smaller record labels.

FAQs.question: In what ways do you work to ensure that you are staying ahead of trends and consumer preferences? Have you been able to stay on top of trends in the past?
FAQs.answer: Labels must be able to identify and capitalize on changes in consumer taste in order to remain competitive. The music industry is extremely competitive, and labels can't afford to be late identifying new trends in the style of music that consumers are listening to.

FAQs.question: How have declining album sales affected your revenue? Have you been able to capitalize on the rise of streaming platforms?
FAQs.answer: Sales of both physical and digital albums serve as a strong indicator of the industry's performance but have been declining in recent years. Much of this loss in revenue is being made up through royalties paid by streaming services, like Spotify or Apple Music.

FAQs.question: How does your customer base break down by age demographics? Can you make it easier for older individuals to purchase or stream music?
FAQs.answer: As labels shift toward online distribution, the industry benefits most from a lower median age of the US population. While younger, more tech-savvy generations have bought into streaming services, it can be more difficult to reach older generations through these relatively new services.

FAQs.question: How has per capita disposable income affected your company's bottom line?
FAQs.answer: Although physical album sales have continually dropped for over a decade, sales of streaming music subscriptions climb as consumer purchasing power rises, benefiting the industry as a whole.
